content.rendered:
In the Name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful

Muslim women have the right to divorce their husbands if the marriage has proven incompatible or the husband is guilty of serious misconduct. Islam provides women with this legal recourse to end a broken marriage or to escape an abusive partner.

There are two avenues for a Muslim woman to divorce her husband: 1) Mutual agreement upon her request (al-khula’), and 2) divorce imposed by a judge (tallaq al-qadi). The first method is preferred because it is more likely to facilitate an amicable separation, which is especially important when children are involved. The second method, on the other hand, is a rather blunt instrument that should only be used when a husband egregiously violates the terms of the marriage contract.

Regarding mutual divorce, a woman may request it from her husband if she finds herself incompatible with him. She must repay the dowry (al-mahr) that she was given at the beginning of the marriage. This is not a penalty against her, but rather a symbolic release of the marriage contract—ensuring fairness if the husband has upheld his obligations.

Allah said:

فَإِنْ خِفْتُمْ أَلَّا يُقِيمَا حُدُودَ اللَّهِ فَلَا جُنَاحَ عَلَيْهِمَا فِيمَا افْتَدَتْ بِهِ ۗ تِلْكَ حُدُودُ اللَّهِ فَلَا تَعْتَدُوهَا

So if you fear they will not be able to keep within the limits of Allah, there is no blame if the wife compensates the husband to obtain divorce. These are the limits set by Allah, so do not transgress them.

Surat al-Baqarah 2:229

Imam al-Nawawi writes:

إذا كرهت المرأة زوجها لقبح منظر أو سوء عشرة وخافت أن لا تؤدى حقه جاز أن تخالعه على عوض

If the wife dislikes her husband because of his ugly appearance, or bad companionship, or she fears she will not fulfill his rights, it is permissible to request a divorce from him on condition of compensation (‘iwad).

Source: al-Majmū’ Sharḥ al-Muhadhab 3/17

And Imam Ibn Qudamah writes:

وَجُمْلَةُ الْأَمْرِ أَنَّ الْمَرْأَةَ إذَا كَرِهَتْ زَوْجَهَا لِخَلْقِهِ أَوْ خُلُقِهِ أَوْ دِينِهِ أَوْ كِبَرِهِ أَوْ ضَعْفِهِ أَوْ نَحْوِ ذَلِكَ وَخَشِيَتْ أَنْ لَا تُؤَدِّيَ حَقَّ اللَّهَ تَعَالَى فِي طَاعَتِهِ جَازَ لَهَا أَنْ تُخَالِعَهُ بِعِوَضٍ تَفْتَدِي بِهِ نَفْسَهَا مِنْهُ

The summary of the matter is that the wife, if she dislikes her husband because of his appearance, his character, his religion, his old age, or his weakness and so on, and she is afraid she will not fulfill the right of Allah Almighty in obedience to him, it is permissible for her to request a divorce from him with compensation by which she frees herself of him.

Source: al-Mughnī 7/323

The first woman recorded to have requested a divorce during the time of the Prophet ﷺ was Habibah bint Sahl, who was married to Thabit ibn Qays. Habibah and Thabit did not get along, so the Prophet facilitated their separation and Habibah repaid the dowry to Thabit.

Yahya ibn Sa’id reported: Habibah bint Sahl was married to Thabit ibn Qays, and Thabit had struck her. When she woke up, she went to the door of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while it was not yet daylight. She said, “Thabit and I cannot be together!” Thabit came, and the Prophet said to him:

خُذْ مِنْهَا وَخَلِّ سَبِيلَهَا

Take what she owes you and let her go her way.

Source: Sunan al-Dārimī 2317, Grade: Sahih

In this case, Thabit had struck her in a moment of conflict—not in a violent or injurious way, but still enough to warrant her alarm and seek dissolution, as Islam permits in such cases. Even so, this sign of incompatibility was considered legitimate grounds for Habibah to request an annulment. She returned the dowry, effectively dissolving the marriage contract.

It is not permissible for a husband who wishes to divorce his wife to impose hardship upon her to compel such compensation. Islam does not allow such loopholes (hiyal) for men to take advantage of their wives.

Allah said:

وَلَا تَعْضُلُوهُنَّ لِتَذْهَبُوا بِبَعْضِ مَا آتَيْتُمُوهُنَّ إِلَّا أَن يَأْتِينَ بِفَاحِشَةٍ مُّبَيِّنَةٍ ۚ وَعَاشِرُوهُنَّ بِالْمَعْرُوفِ

 Do no mistreat them to make them return some of the dowry, unless they are found guilty of adultery. Treat them kindly.

Surat al-Nisa’ 4:19

Imam al-Nawawi commented:

وإن ضربها أو منعها حقها طمعا في أن تخالعه على شئ من مالها لم يجز … فإن طلقها في هذه الحال على عوض لم يستحق العوض

If he hits her or obstructs her rights in anticipation of her request to divorce on condition of repaying something from her property, it is not permissible… If he divorces her in this manner on condition of compensation, he does not deserve compensation.

Source: al-Majmū’ Sharḥ al-Muhadhab 3/17

Suppose the husband is guilty of serious misconduct (nushuz), such as neglect, abandonment, adultery, or domestic violence, which are clear-cut violations of her marital rights. This gives the wife the option to bring her complaint to a judge and have the divorce imposed upon him. Since the husband has violated the marriage contract, he has forfeited any rights he had over her.

One of the most significant misdeeds necessitating a judge-imposed divorce is a husband’s failure to provide adequately for his wife. This is a type of neglect or abandonment, harmful to her both physically and emotionally.

Imam Ibn Qudamah writes:

وَكُلُّ مَوْضِعٍ ثَبَتَ لَهَا الْفَسْخُ لِأَجْلِ النَّفَقَةِ لَمْ يَجُزْ إلَّا بِحُكْمِ الْحَاكِمِ لِأَنَّهُ فَسْخٌ مُخْتَلَفٌ فِيهِ فَافْتَقَرَ إلَى الْحَاكِمِ كَالْفَسْخِ بِالْعُنَّةِ وَلَا يَجُوزُ لَهُ التَّفْرِيقُ إلَّا أَنْ تَطْلُبَ الْمَرْأَةُ ذَلِكَ لِأَنَّهُ لِحَقِّهَا فَلَمْ يَجُزْ مِنْ غَيْرِ طَلَبِهَا كَالْفَسْخِ لِلْعُنَّةِ فَإِذَا فَرَّقَ الْحَاكِمُ بَيْنَهُمَا فَهُوَ فَسْخٌ لَا رَجْعَةَ لَهُ فِيهِ وَبِهَذَا قَالَ الشَّافِعِيُّ وَابْنُ الْمُنْذِرِ

Every case that results in an annulment for her due to issues of spending are only permissible by the ruling of a judge, as a disagreement in regards to an annulment is in need of a judge, similar to an annulment due to impotence. It is not permissible for him to separate them unless that is requested by the wife, as it is her right. It is not permissible without her request, similar to an annulment due to impotence. When the judge separates them, it is an annulment without the possibility of remarriage. This was said by Al-Shafi’i and Ibn al-Mundhir.

Source: al-Mughnī 8/206

Another case discussed by the jurists is the failure of the husband to meet the sexual needs of his wife by swearing an oath never to be intimate with her again (al-‘ila’a). Again, this is an emotionally harmful form of neglect or abandonment.

Allah said:

الَّذِينَ يُظَاهِرُونَ مِنكُم مِّن نِّسَائِهِم مَّا هُنَّ أُمَّهَاتِهِمْ إِنْ أُمَّهَاتُهُمْ إِلَّا اللَّائِي وَلَدْنَهُمْ وَإِنَّهُمْ لَيَقُولُونَ مُنكَرًا مِّنَ الْقَوْلِ وَزُورًا وَإِنَّ اللَّهَ لَعَفُوٌّ غَفُورٌ

Those of you who keep away from your wives by likening them to your mothers, they are not your mothers. Their mothers are none other than those who gave them birth, and most surely they utter a hateful word and a falsehood, yet Allah is Pardoning and Forgiving.

Surat al-Mujadilah 58:2

Imam Ibn Qudamah writes:

وَالطَّلَاقُ الْوَاجِبُ عَلَى الْمُولِي رَجْعِيٌّ سَوَاءٌ أَوْقَعَهُ بِنَفْسِهِ أَوْ طَلَّقَ الْحَاكِمُ عَلَيْهِ وَبِهَذَا قَالَ الشَّافِعِيُّ

Divorce, with the possibility of remarriage, is an obligation upon a husband who swears an oath never to be intimate with his wife, whether he initiates it himself or it is imposed upon him by a judge. This was said by Al-Shafi’i.

Source: al-Mughnī 7/563

Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah commented:

يَجِبُ عَلَى الرَّجُلِ أَنْ يَطَأَ زَوْجَتَهُ بِالْمَعْرُوفِ وَهُوَ مِنْ أَوْكَدِ حَقِّهَا عَلَيْهِ أَعْظَمُ مِنْ إطْعَامِهَا وَالْوَطْءُ الْوَاجِبُ قِيلَ إنَّهُ وَاجِبٌ فِي كُلِّ أَرْبَعَةِ أَشْهُرٍ مُرَّةً وَقِيلَ بِقَدَرِ حَاجَتِهَا وَقُدْرَتِهِ كَمَا يُطْعِمُهَا بِقَدَرِ حَاجَتِهَا وَقُدْرَتِهِ وَهَذَا أَصَحُّ الْقَوْلَيْنِ

A man must be intimate with his wife in a reasonable manner. This is one of her greatest rights over him, even greater than feeding her. Intimacy is said to be obligatory at least once every four months. It has also been said that it is according to her need and his ability, just as he feeds her according to her need and his ability. This is the more correct opinion.

Source: Majmū’ al-Fatāwá 32/271

A husband should be intimate with his wife in a way that satisfies her passions, neither being merely concerned with his own pleasure, nor so rough as to harm her. Islamic law recognizes that sexual neglect is not merely a physical issue, but one that affects emotional well-being and mental health, which are essential to marital harmony.

Imam Ibn Qudamah writes:

ويُسْتَحَبُّ أَنْ يُلَاعِبَ امرأتَه قبلَ الجِمَاعِ لتَنْهَضَ شهوتُها فتنالَ مِن لذَّةِ الجماعِ مثلَ ما نالَ

It is recommended that he foreplay with his wife before intercourse, so that her desire is aroused and she attains the same pleasure of intercourse as he does.

Source: al-Mughnī 10/232

And the Imam writes:

فَإِنْ فرَغَ قبلَها كُرِهَ له النَّزْعُ حتَّى تفْرُغَ … ولأنَّ فى ذلك ضَرَرًا عليها ومَنْعًا لها مِن قَضاءِ شَهْوتِها

If he finishes before her, it is disliked for him to withdraw until she finishes… because that would harm her and prevent her from satisfying her desire.

Source: al-Mughnī 10/233

Divorce is a serious matter in Islam and should only be a last resort, especially when children are involved, after all possible attempts at family arbitration and reconciliation have failed. It is a major sin for a wife to seek a divorce for no good reason.

Thawban reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

أَيُّمَا امْرَأَةٍ سَأَلَتْ زَوْجَهَا طَلَاقًا فِي غَيْرِ مَا بَأْسٍ فَحَرَامٌ عَلَيْهَا رَائِحَةُ الْجَنَّةِ

Whenever a woman asks her husband for a divorce without a strong reason, the fragrance of Paradise becomes forbidden for her.

Source: Sunan Abī Dāwūd 2226, Grade: Sahih

A wife who is considering a divorce must sincerely evaluate the reasons for such a separation on account of this dire warning. This is because divorce is the most hateful of lawful things to Allah, allowed as a necessity but never desirable in itself.

Abdullah ibn Umar reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

أَبْغَضُ الْحَلَالِ إِلَى اللَّهِ الطَّلَاقُ

The most hateful of lawful matters to Allah is divorce.

Source: Sunan Abī Dāwūd 2172, Grade: Sahih

That said, misconduct by the husband, such as abuse, abandonment, or adultery, is solid ground for a wife to seek a divorce imposed by an Islamic judge. The Prophet ﷺ himself intervened on behalf of a woman who was being violently beaten by her husband, setting a legal precedent for authorities to rectify the situation.

Ali ibn Abi Talib reported: The wife of Al-Walid ibn ‘Uqbah came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and she complained to him, saying, “O Messenger of Allah! Al-Walid has beaten me!” The Prophet said:

قُولِي لَهُ قَدْ أَجَارَنِي

Say to him, ‘He has protected me.’

She did not stay but for a while until she returned, and she said, “He did not give me anything but more beatings!” The Prophet tore a piece of cloth from his shirt, saying:

قُولِي لَهُ إِنَّ رَسُولَ اللَّهِ قَدْ أَجَارَنِي

Say to him, ‘Verily, the Messenger of Allah has given me his protection!’

She did not stay but for a while until she returned, and she said, “He did not give me anything but more beatings!” The Prophet raised his hands, saying:

اللَّهُمَّ عَلَيْكَ الْوَلِيدَ أَثِمَ بِي مَرَّتَيْنِ

O Allah, you must deal with Al-Walid, for he has sinned against me twice!

Source: Musnad Aḥmad 1257, Grade: Sahih

As such, it is the right of a Muslim woman to seek divorce from a judge whenever she is the victim of abuse by her husband (al-tatliq bil-darar), whether that abuse is physical, verbal, or emotional, while she is under no obligation to compensate him or return her dowry. Even without witnesses or physical evidence, a woman’s testimony of harm alone can be sufficient for a judge to consider divorce—especially when corroborated by other behavior or context.

Imam Khalil writes:

ولَهَا التَّطْلِيقُ بِالضَّرَرِ ولَوْ لَمْ تَشْهَدِ الْبَيِّنَةُ بِتَكَرُّرِهِ وعَلَيْهِمَا الإِصْلاحُ وإِنْ تَعَذَّرَ وإِنْ أَسَاءَ الزَّوْجُ طَلَّقَا بِلا خُلْعٍ

She has the right to divorce on the grounds of harm, even if there is no evidence that it has happened repeatedly. They must try to reconcile, but if that is not possible, they are divorced without requiring the husband’s consent or her compensation (khul’).

Source: Mukhtaṣar Khalīl 1/111

Imam al-Majlisi commented on this statement:

ولها التطليق بالضرر هو أن لا يعاشرها بالمعروف واعلم أن المعاشرة بالمعروف من حقها عليه كما أن ذلك من حقه عليها

She has the right to divorce on the grounds of harm, which is that he does not treat her kindly. Know that treating her kindly is her right over him, just as it is his right over her.

Source: Lawāmi’ al-Durar fī Hatk Astār al-Mukhtaṣar 6/640

Imam al-Khattab al-Maliki commented:

مِنْ الضَّرَرِ قَطْعُ كَلَامِهِ عَنْهَا وَتَحْوِيلُ وَجْهِهِ فِي الْفِرَاشِ عَنْهَا وَإِيثَارُ امْرَأَةٍ عَلَيْهَا وَضَرْبُهَا ضَرْبًا مُؤْلِمًا

Harmful acts include cutting off his speech to her, turning his face away from her in bed, preferring another woman over her, and hitting her painfully.

Source: Mawāhib al-Jalīl fī Sharḥ Mukhtaṣar Khalīl 4/17

And Imam al-Dasuqi writes:

للزوجة التطليق على الزوج بالضرر وهو ما لا يجوز شرعا كهجرها بلا موجب شرعي وضربها كذلك وسبها وسب أبيها

The wife may have a separation from her husband due to harm caused that is not legally permissible, such as abandoning her without a legal necessity, or striking her likewise, or cursing her or her parents.

Source: al-Sharḥ al-Kabīr wa Ḥāshiyat al-Dasūqī 2/345

All of this demonstrates that a Muslim woman is not locked into a harmful marriage. She has the right to seek a divorce from the judge when her marital rights are violated, especially when she is hurt. However, if family arbitration or reconciliation is not possible, they should attempt to divorce amicably on mutual grounds before involving coercive authorities.

Allah said:

وَإِنِ امْرَأَةٌ خَافَتْ مِن بَعْلِهَا نُشُوزًا أَوْ إِعْرَاضًا فَلَا جُنَاحَ عَلَيْهِمَا أَن يُصْلِحَا بَيْنَهُمَا صُلْحًا وَالصُّلْحُ خَيْرٌ

If a woman fears from her husband contempt or evasion, there is no sin upon them if they make terms of settlement between them, for settlement is best.

Surat al-Nisa’ 4:128

In sum, Islam does not lock women into misery. It grants them dignity, autonomy, legal recourse, and escape from abusers. Muslim women may obtain a divorce by mutual agreement with the husband, requiring her to repay the dowry, or by the imposition of a judge in cases of abuse, abandonment, or adultery. A wife has no obligation to stay with a man who habitually mistreats her, physically or emotionally, or otherwise violates her sacred marital rights as enshrined in the marriage contract. A husband and wife should attempt to reconcile their differences through family arbitration, especially when children are involved. However, if they must divorce, they should do so amicably before involving coercive authorities as a last resort.

Success comes from Allah, and Allah knows best.
